instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP3V3S5_EN: What is PP3V3S5_EN? PP3V3S5_EN is a typo ofP3V3S5_EN_L which is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Trying to diagnose a rush repair <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that was liquid damaged near the top edges of the board. After UC I do have a green light on the charger but no fan spin (SMC Reset is recognized). I have many missing power rails but I do have <SIGNAL>PP3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> with a full 3.3v. On other areas of the board, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> has less than 3.3v (1.7 to be exact) and the board heats up under right under <CHIP>U1000</CHIP> with the charger plugged in. This leads me to believe there is a short or partial short on this power line but because of how large it is, im having a hard time narrowing down where to look. Suggestions? or am I completely wrong in my diagnosis of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> being the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First find out what component is heating up. I hope it is not the CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I would say a high side FET is shorted. Measure resistance to GND on PPBUS. This will probably turn out to be a dead CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah its a straight 0.00 in diode mode. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, Partial <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Probably shorted FET on CPU power supply. The shorted FET will also heat up.
